Executive Summary

Facility Name: Amerigas Transflow Operation
EPA Facility Identifier: 1000 0021 3878 Plan Sequence Number: 1000055263
Data displayed is accurate as of 12:00 AM (EST) Sunday, March 14, 2021
This facility's emergency response program is based upon the following publications and standards:
National Propane Gas Association (NPGA) LP-Gas Safety Handbooks:
Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures and
How to Control LP-Gas Leaks and Fires
Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) Occupational Safety & Health Standards for General Industry
(29 CFR 1910):

Section 38, Employee Emergency Plan and Fire Prevention Plans.
National Fire Protection Association (NFPA):
NFPA-58, the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code and
NFPA-54, the National Fuel Gas Code.
We have discussed this program with the Columbia County Emergency Committee (LEPC) and the South Portland Fire
Department.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes.

Texas regulations. Both plans include procedures for notification of the local fire, law enforcement and medical organizations.
Notification of potentially affected neighbors would be coordinated through the fire department or law enforcement after consultation

The plans are reviewed periodically to ensure that they remains up-to-date, reflecting current activities on site and employees are
trained on their responsibilities in an emergency to ensure prompt response. The EAP is based upon the following guidelines and
standards:
1) NPGA LP-Gas Safety Handbooks: Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures and How To Control LP-Gas Leaks
and Fires.
2) OSHA's Occupational Safety and Health Standards for General Industry, specifically: 29 CFR 1910.38,Emergency Action
Plans,29CFR 1910.39,Fire Prevention Plans,29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and
29 CFR 1910.120,Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response.
3) National Fire Protection Association Guidelines, NFPA 58,Liquified Petroleum Gas Code and NFPA 54 National Fuel Gas Code.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes.

Facility Name: Amerigas El Paso TX Rail Terminal
EPA Facility Identifier: 1000 0023 0653 Plan Sequence Number: 1000055198

with site personnel. Should as actual incident occur, the plans give guidance to employees on how to respond if it is a minor
problem and easily controlled on site. Larger emergencies require assistance from the local emergency response organizations
and employees are knowledgeable as to when that outside assistance is required.

Five Year Accident History

This facility has not had a reportable release of propane in the past five (5) years.

Emergency Response Program

The emergency response plan for this AmeriGas facility includes pro

lting from vapor cloud 
explosion of a cloud containing largest quantity of regulated substance from a vessel or process 
pipe failure. Per CFR 68.25.b.1, For substances in a vessel, the greatest amount held in a vessel, 
taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity is the worst-case Scenario.

The greatest amount of propane held is 30,000 Gallons or 110,000 lbs. The total quantity released 
was 110,000 lbs. The propane was assumed to disperse in the flammable range, encounter areas 
of sufficient congestion and confinement and result in a vapor cloud explosion.
Using EPA RMP Comp, the calculated worst-case distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.4 miles.


Assumption
RMP assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario of atmospheric stability 
class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour). Ambient 
air temperature assumed is 25 deg C (77 deg F). TNT-equivalent model is used which assumes 
a yield factor of 10 percent.

Alternative Release Scenario
For alternative release scenario, release from transfer hoses at the facility was chosen. The active 
mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limiting the release to the contents of the 
hose. The calculated distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.02 miles.

Broken or burst propane loading hoses were determined to be the most common failure. Pumps 
and Compressors were also considered. Maintenance and mitigation devices are in place that 
would mitigate the risks of release from pumps and compressors. Vessel overfilling is mitigated 
administratively. The storage tanks are filled only to a maximum of 85% of the total capacity to allow expansion of the product. 
 

Emergency Response Plan, Accidental Release Program and Specific Prevention Steps:
Though the site is classified as a non-responding facility, it maintains an Emergency Ac

te and the company continually strive to improve operations performance including the prevention of incidents, injuries and
releases at the facility. Primary elements of this continuous improvement effort include making capital improvements to the facility
as required, maintaining up to date procedures and continual training of personnel in both regulatory and job specific subject matter.
The integrity and reliability of major equipment, including pumps, compressors, pipelines and storage tanks is assured through
periodic inspection and preventive maintenance practices. The chemicals handled do not present significant internal corrosion
hazards and corrosion to external surfaces of pipelines and storage tanks is minimized via extensive inspection and painting
programs.

As important as those previously mentioned items are, emergency shutdown systems and portable fire extinguishers are also
available on site. The emergency shutdown systems include the ability to activate via remote control, positive shutoff valves
designed to shutdown the affected equipment or isolate a problem once it is detected.

This distribution and storage facility is subject to and abides by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) rule for sites handling
hazardous chemicals. In addition, the site complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and all other applicable federal,
state and local codes. When built, this facility was designed in accordance with NFPA-58.
All of our AmeriGas transport drivers are trained in the terminal's loading & emergency action plan procedures and future plans
include driver certification using the National Propane Gas Association (NPGA) Certified Employee Training Program (CETP).

Worst-Case Scenario and Alternative Scenario

For flammables, vapor cloud explosion is specified as worst case scenario. Worst case scenario

Facility Background and Corporate Commitment to Safety

At the AGP Montoya TX  facility we handle propane that is recognized by the EPA as a regulated, flammable substance. The same
properties that make propane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling it to
prevent leaks, spills and accidents. First and foremost in our operations are the efforts undertaken to ensure employee and
contractor safety while on site as well as to minimize the risk exposure for the surrounding communities. It is our company policy to
adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations.


As a corporation, AmeriGas staffs a professional Safety Department at our Corporate Headquarters in King of Prussia,
Pennsylvania. AmeriGas also has nine Regional Logistics Managers, a Director of Terminals, a Regulatory Compliance Manager
and a Supply and Logistics Safety Manager strategically located throughout the United States. These safety professionals are able
to immediately respond to a serious incident and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the
scene of the incident. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center, which handles all afterhours
and emergency calls from around the country. Located in Rocklin, California, the ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas
field personnel, as well as Chemtrec, on any type of incident encountered at any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.
The primary purpose of the facility is to store and distribute propane to AmeriGas retail facilities and wholesale customers. Propane
is received by rail cars then distributed to the customers by truck transports. Access to the site is restricted to authorized
employees, management personnel and contractors by the use of perimeter fencing and controlled gate access.
